1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which has the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name               | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Chlorine System              Chlorine                                    24,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared

a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

Facility Layout

The City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant operates a wastewater treatment plant in Hanford, CA. The facility has a chlorine system that is used as needed to disinfect wastewater in several different areas of the wastewater treatment plant:
 
Secondary Sedimentation Basins
Chlorine Basins
The re-circulation structure
Oxidation Ditch
 
Chlorine System Equipment
The process operates as follows: six ton containers are connected to the wastewater treatment process through process tubing and piping. Chlorine gas is withdrawn from the ton containers by vacuum. This vacuum opens the vacuum regulator diaphragm and withdraws the chlorine gas from the ton containers at a controlled feed rate set by the operators with the use of the chlorine feed regulator and rotameter mounted to the wall. The gas is injected into the feed water line where it becomes a chlorine/water solution and is distributed to the location where it is needed in the treatment process. The analyzers monitor chlorine concentrations in the water and relay the information to the chlorine feed regulator in order to determine whether more or less chlorine should be injected.
 
Process Chemistry

At the City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant chlorine gas (Cl2) is used for disinfection of water distributed to residential and irrigation customers. The chlorine, when added to water, yields both hydrochloric (HCl) and hypochlorous (HOCl) acid (see chemical equation below) in aqueous solution. This combination is effective for killing bacteri

a, viruses, pathogens and other micro-organisms. Note that the equation below is easily reversible which results in "off-gassing" of chlorine gas from water that contains high concentrations of the acids.

The chlorination process begins with the chlorine gas being drawn from the ton containers through a pressure reducing valve, reduced to vacuum at a vacuum regulator valve mounted inside a chlorinator, metered through a manually-adjusted rate valve, and finally injected into water. 

Safety Systems
The City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant is equipped with multiple self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBAs) for changing the tanks. 
All ton containers are chocked and stored securely in the chlorine storage area or the chlorine building pursuant to Sections 2.6, 2.7, and 2.8 of the Chlorine Institute's Chlorine Manual. The chlorine building is not exposed to vehicular traffic and is locked after normal working hours. 
Chlorine is fed through a vacuum regulator that ensures that the tubing containing chlorine operates in a vacuum. In the event that the vacuum is lost, the regulator will shut off chlorine feed.
Each chlorine ton container at the City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant is protected from overpressure with three (3) fusible plugs on each side of the container (6 total). The fusible plugs consist of a brass plug with a fusible metal insert that is designed to melt between 157ºF-170ºF.
Various analog gauges are installed throughout the chlorine process for continuous monitoring of container weight and pressure. The ton containers in the chlorine building are also placed on a load-cell scale for additional container weight monitoring.
Emergency eyewash and safety showers are located in various areas throughout the facility including in the chlorine building and can be used to decontaminate if chemical exposure occurs. 
The chlorine building is equipped with an emergency ventilation fan that is interlocked with the chlorine detection system and automa

tically activates at 2 ppm. 
 
Process Classification

The chlorine process at the City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant utilizes multiple ton containers. The ton containers in the storage area are not interconnected to the ton containers being utilized in the chlorine building, but are co-located in such a way that it is foreseeable that multiple containers could be involved in a simultaneous release. Therefore, all ton containers at the City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant are considered a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of chlorine in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the chlorine process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Chlorine

The chlorination process at the City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant facility is an integral part of the overall business. The chlorination process utilizes six 2,000 lbs. containers, with another three containers stored outside in the chlorine storage area. Process management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of a chlorine leak. 

City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant personnel monitor the chlorination process. In addition, the process is checked frequently by our outside water treatment contractor. This contractor also assists in performing the annual mechanical integrity review of our chlorine equipment. 
1.4 Five Year Accident History

City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant has had no accidental release with

in the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR §1910.38
- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR §5189(n)
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR §1910.119(n)
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 §2765.1-2765.2
- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR §68.95
- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 §2731

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMW

riter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program City of Hanford Wastewater Treatment Plant will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
